description:
From Middle English instrument, from Old French instrument, from Latin īnstrūmentum (“an implement, tool”),
From īnstruō (“build, construct; arrange”) +‎ -mentum.

entries.meaning: A device used to produce music.
examples: The violinist was a master of her instrument.

entries.meaning: A means or agency for achieving an effect.

examples: The instrument detected an increase in radioactivity.

definitionGroups.group: A tool, implement used for manipulation or measurement.

entries.meaning: (aviation, usually in the plural) Ellipsis of flight instrument.
examples: Flight within clouds must be made by reference to your instruments.

entries.meaning: (law) A legal document, such as a contract, deed, trust, mortgage, power, indenture, or will.
examples: A bond indenture is the instrument that gives a bond its value.
Negotiable instruments are the foundation of the debt markets.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A person used as a mere tool for achieving a goal.
examples: The bold are but the instruments o' the wise.

verbs.description: instrument (third-person singular simple present instruments, present participle instrumenting, simple past and past participle instrumented)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To devise, conceive, cook up, plan.
To perform upon an instrument; to prepare for an instrument.
